 The Bail Reform Act of 1984 (Act) requires courts to detain prior to trial arrestees charged with certain serious felonies if the Government demonstrates by clear and convincing evidence after an adversary hearing that no release conditions “will reasonably assure . . . the safety of any other person and the community.” 18 U.S.C. § 3142(e) (1982 ed., Supp. III).  While we agree that a primary function of bail is to safeguard the courts' role in adjudicating the guilt or innocence of defendants, we reject the proposition that the Eighth Amendment categorically prohibits the government from pursuing other admittedly compelling interests through regulation of pretrial release. The above-quoted dictum in Stack v. Boyle is far too slender a reed on which to rest this argument. The Court in Stack had no occasion to consider whether the Excessive Bail Clause requires courts to admit all defendants to bail, because the statute before the Court in that case in fact allowed the defendants to be bailed. Thus, the Court had to determine only whether bail, admittedly available in that case, was excessive if set at a sum greater than that necessary to ensure the arrestees' presence at trial.
 
 The holding of Stack is illuminated by the Court's holding just four months later in Carlson v. Landon, 342 U.S. 524 (1952). In that case, remarkably similar to the present action, the detainees had been arrested and held without bail pending a determination of deportability. The Attorney General refused to release the individuals, “on the ground that there was reasonable cause to believe that [their] release would be prejudicial to the public interest and would endanger the welfare and safety of the United States.” Id., at 529 (emphasis added). When this clause was carried over into our Bill of Rights, nothing was said that indicated any different concept. The Eighth Amendment has not prevented Congress from defining the classes of cases in which bail shall be allowed in this country. Thus, in criminal cases bail is not compulsory where the punishment may be death. Of course, to determine whether the Government's response is excessive, we must compare that response against the interest the Government seeks to protect by means of that response. Thus, when the Government has admitted that its only interest is in preventing flight, bail must be set by a court at a sum designed to ensure that goal, and no more. Stack v. Boyle, supra.  Sinjin, 
 
 Well none of the links posted so far go to the actual law, at least as far as I can see. I did goggle it and found a Colorado Bureau of Investigations webpage that tells people what to do if their firearm purchase was denied because of an old arrest on their record that did not show the final outcome of the charge: Colorado Department of Public Safety
 
 From what I can gather this looks like an instant check issue concerning the accuracy of criminal record histories maintained in Colorado. Colorado appears to use a computerized instant check background check system similar to Virginia’s, in which the purchaser has his record checked for approval while he is in the store. 
 
 In Virginia the State Police run the instant check system, and they run the purchaser’s info through the national database, NCIC, and the Virginia database, called VCIN. It is the same record check information that I see every day at work, except that records I request for investigation purposes are printed out and temporarily stored in the file of the defendant the record was run on. 
 
 I think I’ve got an idea of what’s going on in Colorado, but let me first explain how the record check system works. All this information is put into a state-wide database by the local jurisdiction (which shares it with the national NCIC system). Say a warrant or indictment is issued charging me with a crime. The locality is responsible for inputting that information into the database. In many cases this is done even before I am arrested if the warrant is obtained before my arrest. One purpose for this is to let any other agency in the nation who happens to pull me over and run my license know instantly that I am wanted in the local jurisdiction for the charged crime. The info will include the description of the charged crime and whether it is a felony or misdemeanor. It will list the jurisdiction and contain the date the charge was filed. It will also immediately list the outcome as “disposition not received,” which means that the local jurisdiction has not posted the outcome of the charge yet. Until the case is finished this is what an instant check computer record check operator will see if I try to buy a gun at a dealer. 
 
 It is the responsibility of the local agency to report the outcome of the case once it is finished (thereby making it available for the instant check operator to see it). Once that outcome is reported the electronic criminal record for that charge will change from “disposition not received” to read (I’ll use Virginia data entries for examples) something like “guilty”, “not guilty”, “dismissed” (if, for example, it was thrown out on a technicality and not an acquittal on the merits), and “Nolle Prosequi” (where a Va. Prosecutor dropped the charge but has leave to bring it back again).
 
 Virginia has a pretty good track record of reporting these dispositions to NCIC, but I do occasionally see records that show “disposition not received” for very old charges—and that is the fault of the local jurisdiction for not reporting what happened to the case (I see it a lot with charges from other states, quite frankly). In Colorado I do not know if that end result reporting duty rests with the local law enforcement agency or (more properly) with the clerks of the court the case was finished in. 
 
 This is how the information is supposed to get into the system to be checked when I go buy a gun. Now let me compare Virginia to what I can see of Colorado’s system, and use a felony charge as an example. Both states will block the sale if the instant check system shows a felony conviction. If, however, the charge still lists “disposition not received,” then the states appear to do different things. 
 
 Virginia permits the sale without any further obligation on the buyer to do anything, and requires the dealer to deliver the transaction form to the State Police, which is charged with immediately researching the matter to determine whether a disqualifying conviction was not recorded properly. If the State Police find this to be so, then that agency immediately notifies the dealer and the local law enforcement agency of the problem. Virginia can do it this way without burdening the purchaser because our criminal record infrastructure is able to ensure a high degree of accuracy with Instant Check. The burden therefore rests with the state to make sure the system is accurate up front—something Virginia does very well. 
 
 Colorado, on the other hand, appears to block the sale and puts the burden on the purchaser to go get the court documents from the local jurisdiction showing that the charge was ended without a conviction. The burden therefore rests with the person who wants to clear his name because a local official did not report the proper outcome of his charge. 
 
 What I say from here on is based upon the above assumption of Colorado’s system. If I have misunderstood that system then I invite correction on it. But if this is the system, then I have mixed feelings about it. Remember that before Instant Check we were forced to endure an old “snail mail” background check process that used to take up to two weeks of mailing back and forth before you got an answer approving the sale. The federal “Brady Bill” Instant Check scheme was supposed to get rid of the delay, and the NRA (and I) supported it because it promised to be accurate enough to remove the delay by making accurate records instantly reviewable. After all, if the records could be accurately checked instantly then the reason for the delay in the purchase goes away—despite the ill intentions of those who wanted to continue to force weeks of delay on us. But I agree that if the records are inadequate then instant check should be abandoned in that case to make sure the person can legitimately have the gun. So in theory I don’t have a problem with Colorado’s “wait and check to make sure if the arrest does not show a disposition” process. 
 
 BUT, I read in the article Sinjin cited from February 2, 2000: 
 
 “No one list tracks those arrested all the way through court. Colorado officials are working on a computer program that will match arrests with what happened to the suspects in court. But that system, by its best measure, is only 35 percent effective.” (emphasis added)
 
 This to me is unacceptable, and here is why:
 
 Someone mentioned earlier in this thread that the Colorado “deny it first and make the buyer prove he was found not guilty when the system doesn’t show it” system went back to 1994. That’s probably true, for that was when the federal Brady Act was signed and Instant Check came online nationwide. I bet at that time Colorado’s criminal record history database, reporting procedures, and local reporting habits were not complete enough to handle Instant Check. That is, Colorado probably did not have the infrastructure in place to handle Instant Check and make it fully reliable in 1994 (unlike, I’m proud to say, Virginia’s system, which was ready and accurate enough). Therefore, at that time they had a justification for having a delay to make sure the records were right (although I do have a problem with placing this duty on the buyer to support the indifference, laziness, or incompetence of the state reporting system)
 
 But six years later and the system can be accurate, at best, only 35% of the time? It appears they did very little to fix the problem in the six years from 1994 to 2000. Is that the fault of the gun buyer? Should he have had to wait six years to be told “we can still only get it right 35% of the time, so we have decided to continue to make you carry our water for us if we fail to report you were acquitted of the crime”?
 
 I understand from reading further that there is supposed to be a 2010 “sunset” of this “auto-denial for an arrest that does not show a disposition—and make the buyer fix our mistake for us” law. My guess is that the legislature set this up because it planned to build up Colorado’s system to make Instant Check reliable enough within those ten years from 2000 until now—thereby taking away the need for the burdensome law. 
 
 So what has been going on in Colorado for the last decade? I read with interest in Sinjin’s article that some legislators ten years ago trumpeted their defiance of the NRA and that they were proud to have kept the burden on the gun buyer to make sure the state accurately recorded his criminal record history. And now I see it appears that either they or others cut from the same cloth want to remove the sunset of that law and keep it around. So I ask again, what have they done in the last decade to fix the problem? Have they been able to get their accuracy rate over the 50% mark yet? Apparently not, since some of these legislators want to keep the same burden of fixing the problem on the buyer. So have they really done anything in ten years to fix this record history recording problem, or have they simply refused to address it because they wanted to keep it around as an excuse to continue to unduly burden the gun buyer? Did they all along intend to let the criminal records reporting problem fester because they didn’t like Instant Check in the first place and never intended to comply with it?
 
 All I can say is that in Colorado inadequate Instant Check records must still be the norm to justify a move to “un-sunset” this burdensome law and keep it around. And since these same models of legislative efficiency have decided not to “reset the sunset” it appears their true motive all along was to make the law permanent—to never fix an issue which honest people saw to be a problem but which they saw as a continued opportunity to harass otherwise innocent firearm purchasers. 
 
 Would you vote for a guy who promised to fix the potholes in your city, and who six years later said we’ve only got 35% of them filled? I doubt it.
